message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and colonoscopy findings suggest ulcerative colitis which increases the risk of developing primary sclerosing cholangitis. Cholangiocarcinoma and hepatocellular carcinoma are not associated with ulcerative colitis. Primary biliary cirrhosis is not related to ulcerative colitis or the symptoms described.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of intermittent bloody diarrhea and abdominal pain, as well as the colonoscopy and biopsy findings, suggest the patient has ulcerative colitis, which is strongly associated with primary sclerosing cholangitis. Other options are not associated with ulcerative colitis.

We refer to the Wikipedia article on inflammatory bowel disease for help. The patient's symptoms and colonoscopy findings suggest ulcerative colitis, which is associated with an increased risk of developing primary sclerosing cholangitis. None of the other options are associated with ulcerative colitis or its complications.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and colonoscopy findings suggest inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), specifically ulcerative colitis. Patients with long-standing ulcerative colitis are at an increased risk for primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC), which is a chronic liver disease. There is no evidence to suggest that this patient is at an increased risk for the other options.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, including bloody diarrhea and mild tenderness in the right lower quadrant, suggest inflammatory bowel disease, which puts the patient at risk for developing primary sclerosing cholangitis. None of the other options are associated with inflammatory bowel disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The diffuse erythema with a sandpaper pattern involving the rectosigmoid and descending colon suggests the patient has ulcerative colitis. Patients with ulcerative colitis have an increased risk of developing primary sclerosing cholangitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and colonoscopy findings suggest ulcerative colitis, which is associated with an increased risk of primary sclerosing cholangitis. Cholangiocarcinoma and hepatocellular carcinoma are associated with chronic hepatitis and cirrhosis, while primary biliary cirrhosis is autoimmune and not directly related to ulcerative colitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and colonoscopy findings suggest ulcerative colitis, which puts him at risk for developing primary sclerosing cholangitis. Cholangiocarcinoma and hepatocellular carcinoma are not related to ulcerative colitis, and primary biliary cirrhosis is not associated with bloody diarrhea.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, including bloody diarrhea and abdominal pain, are indicative of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), specifically ulcerative colitis. Ulcerative colitis has been associated with an increased risk for primary sclerosing cholangitis. None of the other options are associated with IBD.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and the findings from colonoscopy and biopsy suggest inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), specifically ulcerative colitis. Patients with IBD are at increased risk for developing primary sclerosing cholangitis. Cholangiocarcinoma and hepatocellular carcinoma are not directly related to IBD, and primary biliary cirrhosis is not associated with IBD.
